fr.reflexe.viewshell.api.data.types

Interface IRelationType

  • All Superinterfaces:
    IType

    public interface IRelationType
extends IType
    Cell data type representing a relationship between entities, such as a foreign key (for a relational database) or a link relationship (for a graph database).

    In complex models, the relation type may be composed of multiple types and data values. Additionally, in (very) complex models, the number of source cells may be different from the number of target cells. In conventional (non-composite) relationship models, there is one type and only one associated data value.

    For a relational (SQL-type) database, the type of the actual field will probably derive from INTEGER or VARCHAR. Graph databases may return other types and provide access to link attributes (the edge) via the cell data value.

    Thread safety: implementations are required to be immutable and therefore completely thread-safe.

    Since:
    1.0
    Author:
    REFLEXE Technologies

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      List<IType> getCompositeSourceTypes()
      Gets the ordered list of all source data types in this cell structure that define the relationship, ordered by "most restrictive first".
      List<ICell> getCompositeTargetCells()
      Gets the ordered list of all target cells in the related cell structure, ordered by "most restrictive first".
      ICell getRelationCell()
      Gets the relationship target cell in the related source (which will generally be the primary key cell in the parent table for relational SQL databases if this is a foreign key).
      IType getRelationType()
      Gets the relationship type (which will be the column type in a table for relational SQL databases).
      boolean isComposite()
      Indicates if this is a complex composite relationship type (multiple values and types defining the relationship).

    • Method Detail

      • isComposite

        boolean isComposite()
        Indicates if this is a complex composite relationship type (multiple values and types defining the relationship).

        Connectors may alternatively define such relationships as a series of cells with auto-fill providers that enumerate restricting cells. It is not recommended to mix these alternative approaches in the same model.

        When this returns true, then you must use getCompositeSourceTypes() instead of getRelationType(), and getCompositeTargetCells() instead of getRelationCell().

        Returns:
        true if this is a composite relationship type.
        Since:
        1.0

      • getRelationType

        IType getRelationType()
        Gets the relationship type (which will be the column type in a table for relational SQL databases).

        For SQL databases, this corresponds to the relationship defined by the REFERENCES expression within a CREATE TABLE statement. It therefore defines the physical relationship, which is not the same as the semantic "relation column" (flags 1 and 2) used by OpenAGE Designer.

        Returns:
        the datatype of the relation cell in the source cell structure. The datatype of the related cell in the target cell structure can be retrieved from the relation cell, which returns the target cell type.
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - if this is a composite relation type.
        Since:
        1.0

      • getRelationCell

        ICell getRelationCell()
        Gets the relationship target cell in the related source (which will generally be the primary key cell in the parent table for relational SQL databases if this is a foreign key).

        For SQL databases, this corresponds to the relationship defined by the REFERENCES expression within a CREATE TABLE statement. It therefore defines the physical relationship, which is not the same as the semantic "relation column" (flags 1 and 2) used by OpenAGE Designer.

        To obtain semantic labels for display (instead of displaying the key value), use ICell.getLabelProvider() instead. When using an OpenAGE connector, the label provide will by default return the "flag 1" field value.

        Note: cyclic references are possible and care should therefore be taken to avoid introducing infinite loops.

        Returns:
        the target cell in a different source of the same connector. The datatype of the target cell must be compatible with the datatype of the relation cell. May return null if the model is in an inconsistent state.
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - if this is a composite relation type.
        Since:
        1.0

      • getCompositeSourceTypes

        List<IType> getCompositeSourceTypes()
        Gets the ordered list of all source data types in this cell structure that define the relationship, ordered by "most restrictive first". The order is consistent with getCompositeTargetCells(), and IRelationData.getCompositeSourceValues(). The most restrictive element is always the "parent" element of a parent-child relationship (note that the list may contain 1..n elements).
        Returns:
        an ordered list, never null. If this is not a composite relation type, then the list will contain the value getRelationType().
        Since:
        1.0

      • getCompositeTargetCells

        List<ICell> getCompositeTargetCells()
        Gets the ordered list of all target cells in the related cell structure, ordered by "most restrictive first". The order is consistent with getCompositeSourceTypes(), and IRelationData.getCompositeSourceValues(). The most restrictive element is always the "parent" element of a parent-child relationship (note that the list may contain 1..n elements).
        Returns:
        an ordered list, normally consistent with the source data, except for (very) complex models that may merge data differently between the source and target. May return an empty list if the model is in an inconsistent state.
        Since:
        1.0
